papers.title: Parallaxes, Proper Motions, and Near-Infrared Photometry for 173 L and T Dwarfs From The US Naval Observatory Infrared Astrometry Program
papers.abstract: We present near-infrared parallax and proper motion astrometry for 74 L-dwarfs and 99 T-dwarfs, as single objects or in binary systems, obtained with the ASTROCAM astrometric imager on the USNO, Flagstaff Station 1.55-m telescope over two observing periods. For all 173 objects the median number of observational epochs was 62 with a median time frame of 5.25 years, resulting in median uncertainties of $σ$($π_{abs}$) = 1.51 mas, $σ$($μ_{abs}$) = 1.02 mas yr$^{-1}$, and $σ$($V_{\rm tan}$) = 1.01 km s$^{-1}$. Our observations provide the first parallax/proper motion results for 16 objects and the highest precision parallaxes/proper motions for an additional 116 objects. A serendipitous overlap of 40 objects with Gaia DR3 astrometry allows direct comparison and confirmation of our results, along with an investigation on the effects of resolved binarity on astrometric results. We also provide a uniform set of $J$-, $H$-, $K_{S}$-band photometry in the UKIRT/MKO system, most of it being from new observations. We use these results to examine objects included in this study of special-interest populations, consisting of binaries, wide companions, young objects, subdwarfs, and brown dwarf spectral standards.

**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to find objects in space that are too dim to see with the naked eye, yet hold crucial clues about how planets and stars form. Brown dwarfs—sometimes called "failed stars"—are cosmic misfits that aren't quite massive enough to shine like our Sun, but are much larger than planets like Jupiter. Understanding these mysterious objects helps us piece together the story of how our galaxy evolved and where planets like Earth might exist. This research provides the most precise measurements ever taken of nearly 200 of these elusive brown dwarfs, creating a cosmic census that will guide astronomers for years to come.

**What They Did**

Using a specialized telescope in Arizona, astronomers spent over five years taking incredibly precise measurements of 173 brown dwarfs. Think of it like cosmic surveying—they measured exactly how far away these objects are (called parallax, similar to how your finger appears to shift when you close one eye, then the other) and how fast they're moving across the sky (proper motion, like tracking a distant airplane's path). They took an average of 62 separate observations of each object over more than five years, allowing them to detect movements smaller than the width of a human hair seen from a mile away. They also captured detailed infrared light measurements, since brown dwarfs glow mostly in heat we can't see with our eyes.

**Key Findings**

The team achieved remarkable precision, measuring distances accurate to within about 1.5 milliarcseconds—imagine splitting a dime into 13 million pieces and measuring just one piece from 200 miles away. They provided the first-ever distance measurements for 16 brown dwarfs and significantly improved measurements for 116 others. Among their subjects were binary pairs (brown dwarfs orbiting each other), unusually young objects, and brown dwarfs with different chemical compositions that tell stories about our galaxy's history.

**Looking Forward**

This precise cosmic census creates a foundation for understanding how common brown dwarfs are in our galaxy and how they relate to planet formation. Future space telescopes will use these measurements to study brown dwarf atmospheres and search for planets orbiting them, potentially expanding our definition of where life might exist in the universe.

papers.title: Constraining the size, shape, and albedo of the large Trans-Neptunian Object (28978) Ixion with multi-chord stellar occultations
papers.abstract: Trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs) are among the most primitive remnants of the early Solar System, and constraining their sizes, shapes, albedos, and surface properties is essential for understanding their origin and evolution. Stellar occultations provide highly accurate size and shape measurements for TNOs, while photometry constrains their albedo and surface colours. (28978) Ixion is one of the largest TNOs and a prominent Plutino, making it a key target for comparative studies. We aim to constrain Ixion's projected size, shape, absolute magnitude, geometric albedo, and surface colours, and to search for evidence of an atmosphere or circum-object material. We analysed stellar occultation campaigns by Ixion conducted between 2020 and 2023 within the Lucky Star collaboration, comprising 51 observations from eight events, including 30 positive detections. Five multi-chord events enabled a global limb fit and an accurate reconstruction of Ixion's projected shape. The occultations reveal a slightly elongated limb well represented by a single projected ellipse, yielding an area-equivalent diameter of $D_{\mathrm{equiv}} = 696.78^{+10.75}_{-8.87}$ km and an apparent oblateness $ε' = 0.081^{+0.004}_{-0.010}$. Typical radial residuals of order $\sim$10 km indicate a largely stable shape across epochs, with modest epoch-dependent variations. Calibrated photometric data yield an absolute magnitude of $H_V = 3.845 \pm 0.006$, a phase-curve slope of $β= 0.1301 \pm 0.0078$ mag deg$^{-1}$, and a visible geometric albedo of $p_V = 0.106^{+0.003}_{-0.003}$, with colours consistent with moderately red TNO surfaces. No atmosphere or circum-object material is detected down to our sensitivity limits. The best-sampled event also allows a precise measurement of the angular diameter of the occulted star Gaia DR3 4056440205544338944, $θ_\star = 0.670 \pm 0.010$ mas.

**Why It Matters**

Far beyond Neptune, in the frozen outer reaches of our solar system, lie ancient chunks of rock and ice that have remained virtually unchanged since the planets first formed 4.6 billion years ago. These "Trans-Neptunian Objects" are like cosmic time capsules, holding clues about how our solar system—and potentially other planetary systems—came to be. Understanding these distant worlds helps us piece together the story of planetary formation and gives us insight into the building blocks that created everything from Mercury to Pluto. Among these frozen relics, some are surprisingly large, approaching the size of dwarf planets, making them crucial targets for understanding how the biggest objects in our solar system's suburbs formed and evolved.

**What They Did**

Scientists used a clever astronomical technique called stellar occultation to measure one of these distant objects, named Ixion. Think of it like watching the shadow of an airplane pass over you during a solar eclipse—when Ixion passed in front of distant stars, it cast a tiny shadow on Earth. By coordinating observations from multiple telescopes across different locations, researchers could trace the outline of this shadow as it swept across our planet. Between 2020 and 2023, they captured eight such events with 51 different telescopes, getting 30 successful measurements. This technique is incredibly precise—like measuring the size of a coin from several miles away—and allows scientists to determine not just how big these objects are, but also their exact shape and whether they have atmospheres.

**Key Findings**

Ixion turned out to be quite substantial—about 697 kilometers across, roughly the size of Texas or twice the width of Germany. It's slightly oval-shaped rather than perfectly round, suggesting it may be spinning rapidly or was shaped by ancient collisions. The object reflects only about 11% of the sunlight that hits it, making it darker than Earth's moon but brighter than charcoal. Its reddish color is typical of objects that have been weathered by billions of years of cosmic radiation. Importantly, the measurements showed no signs of an atmosphere or rings of debris around Ixion, indicating it's a relatively "clean" object in space.

**Looking Forward**

These precise measurements of Ixion provide a new benchmark for understanding large objects in the outer solar system. As we discover thousands of planets around other stars, knowing how planetary building blocks behave in our own cosmic backyard becomes increasingly valuable. This research demonstrates that ground-based telescopes can still make groundbreaking discoveries, complementing space missions to the outer solar system. The techniques developed here will help scientists study other distant objects and may even prove useful for detecting potentially hazardous asteroids closer to home.

papers.title: True Masses using RV data with Hipparcos and Gaia Astrometry
papers.abstract: Long-period companions are detected and characterized thanks to long-baseline radial velocity surveys. Combining Doppler time-series with astrometry, and in particular with proper motion anomalies technique, it is possible to put strong constraints on their orbital inclination and true mass. This work aims to present a model that combines Hipparcos and Gaia astrometric data with radial velocity measurements to constrain the orbital inclinations and true masses of long-period companions. Additionally, we re-analyse a small sample of targets that have not yet been studied using this combined approach. This research leverages the simultaneous modelling of proper motion anomalies and radial velocities, in conjunction with an analysis of the sensitivity curve. This approach serves not only as a verification of the parameters but also as a means to acquire valuable insights into planetary systems. The new analyses reveal that some of the targets classified as brown dwarfs or small-mass stars have a planetary nature. HD 5388 b and HD 6718 b are likely planets. HD 141937 b is likely a planet, but the current dataset does not allow us to firmly constrain its true mass. HD 16760 b belongs to the brown dwarf regime and it has a probable second companion. 30 Ari B b falls within the stellar regime, but the presence of an additional stellar companion could compromise the reliability of the final results. For HD 148427 b, HD 96127 b and HIP 65891 b we determined a range for the orbital inclinations.

**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to weigh your friend while they're on a see-saw in the dark. You can hear the creaking as they move up and down, but you can't see exactly how the see-saw is tilted. This is essentially the challenge astronomers face when studying distant planets orbiting other stars. For decades, we've been detecting these "exoplanets" by watching how they make their host stars wobble, but we haven't been able to determine their true masses—a crucial piece of information for understanding what these worlds are actually like. Knowing whether a distant companion is a planet, a failed star called a brown dwarf, or a small star changes everything about how we understand planetary system formation and the potential for life beyond our solar system.

**What They Did**

The researchers developed a new technique that combines two different ways of studying stellar motion. First, they used radial velocity measurements—tracking how stars move toward and away from us as orbiting companions tug on them gravitationally. Second, they incorporated precise position measurements from space telescopes Hipparcos and Gaia, which can detect tiny changes in a star's position across the sky over many years. By combining these measurements, they could determine the orbital tilt of distant companions and calculate their actual masses, rather than just minimum estimates. Think of it like finally being able to see that see-saw from the side instead of just hearing it creak.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that several objects previously thought to be brown dwarfs or small stars are actually planets. Two companions—HD 5388 b and HD 6718 b—are likely planets rather than the more massive objects they were initially classified as. They also found that HD 16760 b is indeed a brown dwarf and probably has a second companion lurking in the system. Perhaps most intriguingly, they determined that 30 Ari B b falls into the stellar category, though additional companions might be affecting their measurements.

**Looking Forward**

This research opens new possibilities for understanding planetary system architecture and formation. By accurately measuring masses of long-period companions, astronomers can better distinguish between planets and other types of objects, leading to more precise statistics about how common different types of worlds are. As more data from Gaia becomes available, this technique could revolutionize our census of exoplanets, potentially revealing hidden populations of distant worlds that have been misclassified for years.

papers.title: Circumplanetary Disk Candidate in the Disk of HD 163296 Traced by Localized Emission from Simple Organics
papers.abstract: Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array observations suggest that the disc of HD 163296 is being actively shaped by embedded, yet unseen protoplanets, as indicated by numerous gas and dust substructures consistent with planet-disc interaction models. We report the first detection of simple organic molecules, HCN and C2H, tracing a candidate circumplanetary disc (CPD) in the HD 163296 system, located at an orbital radius of $R=88\pm7$ au and azimuth $φ=46\pm3^\circ$ (or $R=0.75''$, $\rm{PA}=350^\circ$ in projected sky coordinates), and originating near the midplane of the circumstellar disc. The signature is localised but spectrally resolved, and it overlaps with a previously reported planet candidate, P94, identified through kinematic perturbations traced by CO lines. We propose a scenario in which the observed chemical anomalies arise from increased heating driven by the forming planet and ongoing accretion through its CPD, facilitating the thermal desorption of species that would otherwise remain frozen out in the disc midplane, and potentially triggering the activation barriers of chemical reactions that lead to enhanced molecular production. Based on a first-order dynamical analysis of the HCN spectrum from the CPD--isolated with a 7$σ$ significance--we infer an upper limit on the planet mass of 1.8 $M_{\rm Jup}$, consistent with predictions from CO kinematics and constraints from direct imaging studies. By comparing the CPD sizes derived from our models with theoretical expectations where the CPD radius corresponds to roughly one-third of the planet's Hill radius, we favor CPD gas temperatures $T > 150$ K, planet masses $M_{\rm p} < 1.0$ $M_{\rm Jup}$, and CPD radii $R_{\rm CPD} < 2$ au.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

For the first time, astronomers have spotted what appears to be a disk of material swirling around a baby planet as it forms—complete with organic molecules that could be the building blocks of life. This discovery gives us an unprecedented peek into how planets like Jupiter are born and helps us understand the early stages of planetary system formation. Since these same processes likely occurred when our own solar system was young, this research provides clues about how Earth and its neighboring planets came to be. The detection of organic molecules in this cosmic nursery also adds another piece to the puzzle of how the chemistry necessary for life spreads throughout the universe.

**What They Did**

Using the powerful Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array telescope in Chile, researchers studied HD 163296, a young star located about 330 light-years away that's surrounded by a massive disk of gas and dust. Think of this disk like a cosmic construction zone where planets are being built from the raw materials swirling around the star. The team specifically looked for the chemical signatures of simple organic molecules—hydrogen cyanide and a carbon compound—that would glow at specific wavelengths when heated. By carefully analyzing these signals, they could map where these molecules were located and how they were moving, like using a chemical fingerprint to identify what's happening in different parts of the disk.

**Key Findings**

The researchers found a concentrated pocket of organic molecules at a specific location roughly 88 times farther from the star than Earth is from the Sun—about twice Neptune's distance in our solar system. This hotspot contained hydrogen cyanide and other organic compounds that shouldn't normally exist in gas form at that cold distance from the star. The team believes they're seeing a circumplanetary disk—essentially a mini version of the larger disk, but wrapped around a forming planet roughly the size of Jupiter. The planet's gravity and heat are warming up the surrounding material enough to vaporize these organic molecules, making them detectable for the first time.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough opens an entirely new way to study planet formation in real-time. Previously, astronomers could only infer the presence of forming planets by looking at gaps and waves in disks, but now they can potentially detect the planets' individual disks and study their chemistry directly. This could help us understand not just how planets form, but how the organic building blocks of life become distributed throughout planetary systems. Future observations might reveal whether these circumplanetary disks are common and what role they play in seeding planets and moons with the materials necessary for life.
